title: 112_s3421
content: The Act may be cited as the "Worker Ownership, Readiness, and Knowledge Act" or the "WORK Act". It focuses on worker ownership, readiness, and knowledge. Definitions in this section include terms like "existing program" for programs promoting employee ownership, "Initiative" for the Employee Ownership and Participation Initiative, "new program" for programs not existing on a certain date, and "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of Labor. The Secretary of Labor will establish an Employee Ownership and Participation Initiative to promote employee ownership and participation in business decision-making. This initiative will support existing programs in states and facilitate the formation of new programs. The Secretary of Labor will support new and existing programs promoting employee ownership and participation in business decision-making by providing federal grants, acting as a clearinghouse for techniques, and disseminating information. The Secretary of Labor will establish a program to encourage new and existing state programs promoting employee ownership and participation in business decision-making. The program established by the Secretary of Labor aims to promote employee ownership and participation in business decision-making within the States by providing education and outreach on the benefits of employee ownership, succession planning, and employee involvement in decision-making processes. The program established by the Secretary of Labor promotes employee ownership and participation in business decision-making by providing technical assistance, training, and funding for employee-owned businesses. The program established by the Secretary of Labor may include provisions targeting key groups such as retiring business owners, senior managers, unions, trade associations, community organizations, and economic development organizations. It also encourages cooperation in organizing workshops and conferences, as well as preparing and distributing materials on employee ownership, participation, and business ownership succession planning. The program established by the Secretary of Labor may include provisions targeting key groups such as retiring business owners, senior managers, unions, trade associations, community organizations, and economic development organizations. It also encourages cooperation in organizing workshops and conferences, as well as preparing and distributing materials on employee ownership, participation, and business ownership succession planning. In the case of activities under paragraph (2)(B), the program provides preliminary technical assistance to employee groups, managers, and retiring owners exploring the possibility of employee ownership, preliminary feasibility assessments, funding for third-party feasibility studies and business valuations, and a data bank for employees to find legal, financial, and technical advice related to business ownership. The Secretary's program includes courses on employee participation and networks of employee-owned companies to spread successful techniques. It also involves visits to existing programs and providing materials for training. The Secretary will issue formal guidance. The Secretary will issue formal guidance for grant recipients and one-stop partners to encourage employee ownership and participation in businesses to increase productivity and broaden capital ownership. Grants may be made for this purpose. The Secretary may make grants for education, outreach, technical assistance, training activities, and cooperation among employee-owned firms. Grants can also be used for training in new programs dedicated to the objectives of this section, with a limit of 10 grants per fiscal year. The Secretary may make grants for education, outreach, technical assistance, and training activities for employee-owned firms. Grants for training shall not exceed 10% of the total grants. The Secretary determines grant amounts and conditions, with applications submitted by entities or states on behalf of local entities. Entities eligible for grants under this section include State or local government units, State-supported higher education institutions, and nonprofit organizations. If a State does not support a program, local entities can apply for grants on their own initiative in subsequent years. States failing to support a program can still submit applications in following years. Entities eligible for grants under this section include State or local government units, State-supported higher education institutions, and nonprofit organizations. Recipients of grants are limited in the amount they can receive each fiscal year, ranging from $300,000 in 2013 to $439,200 in 2017. They are also required to submit annual reports detailing how the grant funds were spent in the previous 12-month period. The Secretary can reserve up to 10% of funds for evaluations and technical assistance. A report on progress and analysis of costs and benefits must be submitted to Congress within 36 months. Authorization of appropriations is provided. For grants under the Initiative, the following amounts are authorized to be appropriated: $3,850,000 for 2013, $6,050,000 for 2014, $8,800,000 for 2015, $11,550,000 for 2016, and $14,850,000 for 2017. Administrative expenses are capped at $350,000 or 5.0% of the maximum grant amount for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2017.
